instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3462: What is 820-3462? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF: What is SMC_ONOFF? SMC_ONOFF is a signal that tells the machine that the power button has been pressed so it knows to turn on, or turn off. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage, got power back, no green light.
threads.message:
Hi guys,

I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that has been liquid damaged.

Initially it was DOA.

<RESISTOR>R6920</RESISTOR> looked burnt so I replaced it and it burnt out again.
Made me look further along. <RESISTOR>R5081</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R4902</RESISTOR> were shorted so I replaced these.

It now turns on and gives a picture but fans are on full and no green light. I think the PCH is getting hot but am not sure what the usual operating temp for this is. I don't fix many newer MBPs.

I swapped out <RESISTOR>R7010</RESISTOR>, as it was reading low, but now the new resistor is reading low too, so there must be a short near by...


Everything seems to measure okay, but I just wanted to describe this behaviour I haven't seen before..

If I plug the charger into [B]my[/B] laptop, it goes green. Plug it into the <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, and it goes green. 

Plug the power into [B]my[/B] laptop again and the light goes orange (mines a little flat now), plug it into the <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> and it goes orange. :|

It seems the light does whatever it was doing last. :/

Any ideas?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage, got power back, no green light.
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage, got power back, no green light.
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 11541"]Disconnect keyboard and try again.[/QUOTE]

No keyboard was connected at the time.

threads.message: Read what again, there was no keyboard connected at the time.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage, got power back, no green light.
threads.message:
Oh, I read that is was connected, sorry.
Is ACOK present? Is <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF</SIGNAL> present?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage, got power back, no green light.
threads.message:
No worries.

<SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL>: 3.389
<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>: 3.42

It boots and feels okay to use, except it never sees the battery.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage, got power back, no green light.
threads.message: Looks like an SMC issue to me.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage, got power back, no green light.
threads.message: I'm interested in how you reached that conclusion with so little info?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage, got power back, no green light.
threads.message:
Experience.
Also resistors don't short. Something went wrong on 3V42 bus, so SMC is 1st suspect now.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage, got power back, no green light.
threads.message: Now I understand your keyboard comment from earlier!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage, got power back, no green light.
threads.message: Keyboard was just to rule out a stuck power button putting the SMC in bypass mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage, got power back, no green light.
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 11601"]Keyboard was just to rule out a stuck power button putting the SMC in bypass mode.[/QUOTE]

Yeh, I realised that after I looking at the <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> in more detail.

threads.message: If I have <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> why would there be no green light?
